messages.content:
Hey everyone 👋

I'm trying to generate a ZK proof that a specific key in a Mina smart contract's off-chain storage had a certain value at a given point in time.

This feels like it should be a straightforward thing to do, even with OffchainState, but I haven't been able to find any example or tutorial showing exactly how to achieve it. I've gone through the docs and the tutorials, but they don't cover my use case.

Could anyone point me to an example or help clarify the right approach to generate such a proof?

Thanks in advance 🙏

Hi there and welcome to Mina!

Last year we have build some "Mastermind zkApp" examples, where part 4 is about offchain storage:

https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/915745847692636181/1314247710890524703

I hope this helps!

thanks @Marc! as far as I can tell by reading through this example, there is a component for settling the offchain storage, but this is not something I'm actually looking for

to be precise, let's forget about the off chain storage now and let's assume that my contract uses only the 8 available memory slots; how can I generate (off-chain) a proof that will certify a value in such slot?

That question is way out of my league 😛

@45930 or @Florian can you help answering the above?

It is actually not very straightforward, as you have mentioned "point in time". It means that you should have some commitment to the state written on L1 at all points in time  to be able to verify the proofs. 

One of the design patterns you can use is to use token accounts, creating a token account to store the root of the Merkle Tree/Map and the time or slot, and later, fetching off-chain right token account, using it to verify the proof.

You can see the examples
https://github.com/Staketab/mina-names/tree/main/contracts

If you would drop the requirement about point in time, it would be much simpler

Florian's team is working on historical preconditions which may make this use case simpler.  The timeline on that feature is not clear yet though.

I'm not aware of a good way to do it now, taking the prompt at face value.  Like DFST said, you can cheat and use a smart contract at time `t` to store some state with a proof that it's correct at that block, then come back at time `t+1` and reference that snapshot in a new proof.

But theoretically, it should be possible to do the proof without setting anything up.  It would just be simpler if the protocol supported the ability to set historical preconditions directly.

thanks @45930 @DFST  a lot for these insights; and what about dropping requirement about point in time? I guess, it then reduces to proving what currently resides at the smart contract's storage, right? do you have any working example of how to do so?

If you want to reference any current state on the chain, it's quite theoretically simple.  I can hunt for an example where one contract references another contract's state.

But in theory, you just have an `AccountUpdate` for that account, and commit to the state you require to be true.  Here's an example of how that looks to the protocol: [sample tx I found](https://minaexplorer.com/transaction/5Jv1mkZYboMbgiwTMhrf5qxivSt2VNWD4SYBit2387WF3ba2HA29)
thanks @45930! does the fact that I need to do it off-chain matters/simplifies anything? I'm interested just in proving and verifying off-chain smart contract state

Ah no, that's a little more difficult.  I don't think we have an example of this case either.  It should be possible, but we don't have tools purpose-built for this.  All of the examples for on-chain proofs in o1js use the account update and precondition model that I mentioned, but that assumes that a node with the full ledger will go roll your transaction into the state proof.

In your case, it sounds like you just want to commit to a state root hash at a given block height and make a proof about account state at in that block with a merkle proof?  I think the process should be straightforward.  I just don't know off the top of my head how the account trees are structured.

If you want, for example, inclusion proofs, then here's what you can do:
- Define your off-chain state
- Define your ZkProgram 1, mutating the state and recursively proving the mutation
- Define another ZkProgram 2 that proves the state for the specific data you want
- Settle on Mina L1 recursive proofs for ZkProgram 1 
- Use Mina state to verify the public input of the proof created with ZkProgram 2 by fetching it with GraphQL or, better, by sending another transaction to L1 that uses a precondition.
There is an example of such [ZkPrograms](https://github.com/SilvanaOne/dex-agent/blob/main/packages/contracts/src/contracts/rollup.ts)

You can convert it to variant with point in time by settling the ZkProgram 1 proofs to token accounts

I would guess it's simpler if they don't want to build a whole rollup app, but just produce a proof like "Given Mina state hash xyz and merkle witness w for account a, prove that the token balance of account a in the state is x"

I just don't know how to properly fetch the merkle witness for an account or reconstruct the state hash.  Do you?
I also don't have an example of doing so, maybe @Faserisko knows

Looks like the `protocol_state.Body` is defined as

```ocaml
module Body = struct
  module Poly = struct
    [%%versioned
    module Stable = struct
      module V1 = struct
        type ('state_hash, 'blockchain_state, 'consensus_state, 'constants) t =
              ( 'state_hash
              , 'blockchain_state
              , 'consensus_state
              , 'constants )
              A.Body.Poly.V1.t =
          { genesis_state_hash : 'state_hash
          ; blockchain_state : 'blockchain_state
          ; consensus_state : 'consensus_state
          ; constants : 'constants
          }
        [@@deriving sexp, equal, compare, yojson, hash, version, hlist]
      end
    end]
  end
```

Then the hash of a new block is computed as

```ocaml
let state_hash =
  Random_oracle.hash ~init:Hash_prefix.protocol_state
    [| (previous_state_hash :> Field.t); (state_body_hash :> Field.t) |]
  |> State_hash.of_hash
```

Where state_body_hash is a hash of the state body struct.
There is a function in js to get the network state: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/4ca3d1751f4905200d4c6be662ef13276e55f74f/src/lib/mina/v1/mina.ts#L221

So @piomiko, what you would have to do to compute a storage proof off chain would be access the Mina ledger and produce a merkle witness of the account you want to prove (may be possible via Mina graphQL endpoint - not sure), then prove the specific value you want in the ledger witness, hash it up with the rest of the network constants and state hash inputs, and assert that the resulting hash is equal to the public hash at a specific block height.  Unfortunately, there isn't a clean example to do all this. You would have to look through the Mina protocol code to get exactly the right inputs and order for the hash, and figure our the right graphQL requests to get those inputs when you need them.

It's way easier prove things on Mina _to_ Mina, since all of that hashing and accessing state is built into the nodes who verify the proof.  But I assume there's a good reason you want this proof to be off chain.
